Package io.github.jdbctemplatemapper.core

Class QueryCount<T>

java.lang.Object
io.github.jdbctemplatemapper.core.QueryCount<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
IQueryCountExecute<T>, IQueryCountFluent<T>, IQueryCountHasOne<T>, IQueryCountJoinColumnTypeSide<T>, IQueryCountType<T>, IQueryCountWhere<T>
public class QueryCount<T> extends Object implements IQueryCountFluent<T>
Gets the count of the records for a query. This is to support pagination counts. 
 See Paginated Queries
Author:
ajoseph

    • joinColumnTypeSide

      public IQueryCountJoinColumnTypeSide<T> joinColumnTypeSide(String joinColumnTypeSide)
      Join column for hasOne relationship: The join column (the foreign key) is on the table of the type model. Example: Order hasOne Customer. The join column(foreign key) will be on the table order (of the type model). The join column should not have a table prefix.
      Specified by:
      joinColumnTypeSide in interface IQueryCountHasOne<T>
      Parameters:
      joinColumnTypeSide - the join column on the type side (with no table prefix)
      Returns:
      interface with the next methods in the chain

    • where

      public IQueryCountWhere<T> where(String whereClause, Object... params)
      The SQL where clause. When querying relationships the where clause can include columns from both type and related tables. The parameters can be positional or named parameters. 
       Examples: 
 1) where("orders.status = ? and orders.customer_id = ?", "COMPLETE", 1) 
 2) where("orders.status = :status and orders.customer_id = :customerId", new
       MapSqlParameterSource().addValue("status", "COMPLETE").addValue("customerId", 1))
      Specified by:
      where in interface IQueryCountJoinColumnTypeSide<T>
      Specified by:
      where in interface IQueryCountType<T>
      Specified by:
      where in interface IQueryCountWhere<T>
      Parameters:
      whereClause - the whereClause for the type.
      params - varArgs for the whereClause.
      Returns:
      interface with the next methods in the chain
